greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle T(n,k) read by rows: T(n,k) is the number of length-n ascent sequences with exactly k descents.
comment: The sequence of column k satisfies a linear recurrence with constant coefficients of order k*(k+5)/2 = A055998(k) for k>0.
Last nonzero elements of rows give A241881(n).
link: Joerg Arndt and Alois P. Heinz, Rows n = 0..140, flattened
example: The 53 ascent sequences of length 5 together with their numbers of descents are (dots for zeros):
There are 16 ascent sequences with no descent, 33 with one, and 4 with 2, giving row 4 [16, 33, 4, 0, 0, 0].
maple: # b(n, i, t): polynomial in x where the coefficient of x^k is   #
#             the number of postfixes of these sequences of     #
#             length n having k descents such that the prefix   #
#             has rightmost element i and exactly t ascents     #
b:= proc(n, i, t) option remember; `if`(n=0, 1, expand(add(
mathematica: b[n_, i_, t_] := b[n, i, t] = If[n == 0, 1, Sum[If[j<i, x, 1]*b[n-1, j, t+If[j>i, 1, 0]], {j, 0, t+1}]]; T[n_] := Function[{p}, Table[Coefficient[p, x, i], {i, 0, n}]][b[n, -1, -1]]; Table[T[n], {n, 0, 12}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Jan 06 2015, translated from Maple *)
program: return sum( ( x if j<i else 1 ) * b(n-1, j, t+(j>i) ) for j in range(t+2) )
xref: Cf. A137251 (ascent sequences with k ascents), A242153 (ascent sequences with k flat steps).
results.author: _Joerg Arndt_ and _Alois P. Heinz_, Mar 06 2014
